comments.commentBody: It's time for bold leadership.  There are no good options, which is why at least three presidents have kicked the can down the road to successor administrations because they've been unwilling to act resolutely.  How's that working out?  Time's up.

The Chinese have already opposed the deployment of a high-altitude missile defense system known as Thaad in South Korea; the Trump team may call for even more such systems.
------------------------
Thaad is a done deal with South Korea, they are being emplaced. Aegis/Thaad systems on Japan's destroyer fleet are operational too. They are a worthy counter to the militarization of vast swaths of the South China Sea by the belligerent, expansionist Chinese who now have a second aircraft carrier in their navy.

This isn't merely a US problem, but one for China, Japan, Russia and Canada, among others.  In the meantime, the current and previous modern US administrations, have been captured by Middle East special interests and the GWOT.  That is, they have been coopted by foreign and foreign-aligned advisory infiltration into all branches of government, and media, that all threats Israeli are all threats US.  Of course, North Korea doesn't have much to offer in natural resource opportunities and isn't particularly strategic geographically.  It is rather curious that 15 years and $7 Trillion later, the US war on terror has accomplished absolutely nothing vis-à-vis actual security threats, unless you believe we are now all safer from Yemenis.  As for a cyber war, leave it to modern warfare theory that computers are effective proxies for face-to-face confrontation and resolution.

First things first.  Trump will focus on North Korea once he finds the wire taps President Obama installed on his phone.  And finds the leakers in his administration.  And kills Obamacare.  And deports 11 million immigrants.

With this kind of logic, it's evident that Trump will do nothing.
Because if there were any wiretaps, he would have already presented evidence to the public.
Once again, FAKE NEWS at its best.

NK has threatened to nuke us on multiple occasions, and they have nukes to do it with. It doesn't take a genius to come to the conclusion that they are our biggest threat, unless of course you are listening to our elected officials who whine about Iran day and night to appease their money lords. Their whine isn't harmless, the guy in Kansas who shot 2 Indian engineers thought they were Iranians as per his own words.

This is why I can't take the fake threat from Russia seriously. It's mostly fabrications to distract the public to advance the neocon agenda. We are supposed to get all bent out of shape over people from Trump team meeting with, or talking to Russians. Oh, the outrage from elected officials who go on their pilgrimage several times a year to get their marching orders from a foreign state.

We are not supposed to cooperate with Russia in Syria against ISIS because that would mean Assad stays in power, which means Iranian influence in Syria continues, and apparently that's not acceptable to our bosses in Tel Aviv.
We need a test of EMP theory, either over N Korea or Iran, or both.
interesting

NK couldn't nuke us if they wanted too and probably won't ever be able to, for many reasons. No one who isn't qualified to assess the NK nuclear threat should contribute to the ancient process of exaggerating a threat, a process that always precedes heightened confrontation and ultimately, armed conflict.
I don't know about intelligent people in the Cuban government Howie, but they lack nuclear capability.  Google the Cuban missile crisis.
Agreed.  I am not a Trump supporter but this is irresponsible reporting.
But obama told us that climate change was our biggest security threat, and he tells President Trump that North Korea is our biggest security threat? I don't know what to think anymore.

Instead of whining about Trump's latest tweet, why doesn't the NYT spend some time publicizing how Obama's weakness failed the American public by not doing his primary job; protecting the American public for the long term. He basically did nothing except try and pass off this problem to his successor.
Really? This country wasn't involved in any major war during the entire Obama administration, and you call this not protecting the American public???
Well, Obama didn't fail me.  He kept us out of war as much as he could.  He tried to disable North Korea.  What would you have had him do, drop a nuke on them?

So, Trump "inherits" a problem even after having been briefed about it by people who know far more about world affairs then he does. He tweets "It won't happen."

All the F-35's in the world won't protect us from this clown.
Yes. Trump "inherits" a problem he would've known more about, had he not skipped so many National Security briefings.

The article explains that the Times has kept much of this information under wraps for a year to keep North Korea from countering the cyber efforts, but the article never explains what changed that makes it OK to publish now.  NYT please explain or risk being accused of publishing for the wrong reasons.
North Korea probably discovered the American cyber interference.

Thank you for your reply Citizen but I do disagree with you.

So. Korea and Japan long ago should have put more pressure on North Korea to end their nuclear program to the point of even bombing their nuclear research facilities.

We are not the world's policeman. Imperialism is over. Iraq 2 war was the last true world for global imperialism.

Yes we should be more friendly to Japan and South Korea than say Iran or No. Korea but not to the point of being their nanny and policeman.
Global warming is capable of annihilating most of it too, with much greater certainty, while humans are yapping about the problems they face today and tomorrow.
Your grasp of history is a bit weak as well.  The Bay of Pigs operation was planned under the Eisenhower administration.

North Korea aspires to be Sparta in contrast to South Korea's Athens. North Korea seeks the nuclear survival insurance enjoyed by the nuclear weapons rogue states India, Pakistan and Israel where the world hypocritically looks the
other way.

North Korea knows what happened to nuclear armed apartheid South Africa. Kim Jung Un knows what happened to the nuclear aspirations of Iraq, Libya and Iran. Germany and Japan are being encouraged by Trump to go nuclear. While Russia and the United States have 9000 nukes which is about 90% of the world total have no moral authority nor credible objective argument against nukes in North Korea.

The Korean War is in a timeout. There was and in no peace treaty that ended that conflict. A family dictatorship wants to stay in power. North Korea spends all on it's massive military. Beneath the nukes is one of the largest conventional military-industrial complexes and armies on Earth. America has not won a war since the end of World War II. Grenada and Panama don't count.

Our troops are not there to threaten China, they are there in response to North Korea's invasion and its large and powerful military. The THAAD system is totally justified given North Korea's missile arsenal.

Further, China's own land grabs in the South China seas are aggressive moves and justify a containment strategy.

Making reference to an old Trump comment, perhaps a sit down, face to face,  meeting with T and KJU would be of value. While it may be The Mad Hatter's Tea Party definitely offering great photo ops, and shouldn't be held in a Malaysian train station, such an encounter could have a positive outcome. So what do you say?
Mad Tweeter's Tea Party is what I say. What a photo op!. Invite Kim Jong-u to Mar-a-Lago...invite Putin....and we could have a Tweeters competition.....
45 is undermining himself without the help of the Dems or anyone else. He is his (and our) own worst enemy.
This is a potentially existential threat. Thank God we have the steady hand and cool head of President Trump to lead us. Right?

"The U.S. has tried to sabotage North Korea's missile program with covert cyber attacks. President Trump must decide what to do next."

Does anyone really think that admitting to "covert" (now, not so much) cyber sabotage against the most unpredictable nuclear power on earth is a good thing? Does anyone further think that telegraphing the likelihood of future cyber attacks against the most unpredictable nuclear power on earth is a good thing?

When one of Kim's rockets "accidentally" falls on Tokyo or Seoul and he states that it was aimed at the middle of the Pacific ocean and blames the US for sabotaging its guidance system who will the NYT blame?
We all seem to think that North Korea is suicidal. If they are, that's scary. Maybe we've been conditioned by the Islamic extremists who have tried to justify suicide attacks.
A wall along the Mexican border?  Maybe Mr. Trump should consider building walls along the east and west coasts to stop the North Korean ICBM's.
This is the only attractive suggestion I've read so far.  But would the Chinese authorities play along?  Would the South Koreans?
I thought the number one threat was Nordstoms and the free press. His ego is our biggest threat.
I think you can safely assume that this is an intentional warning to NK that we are paying attention and are poised to deal with any actualized threat.
And for that, he was naive. Any citizen who pays attention to foreign affairs knows of the increasing threat of a North Korean ICBM.
